clusters.title: Mum's anti-chemo views influenced daughter's death
clusters.neutral_headline: Mum's anti-chemo views influenced daughter's death: Paloma Shemirani died after refusing chemotherapy despite a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

items.title: Mum's anti-chemo views influenced daughter's death
items.standfirst: Paloma Shemirani died after refusing chemotherapy despite a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
items.content: Paloma Shemirani died after refusing chemotherapy despite a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

items.title: UK woman who refused cancer drugs was influenced by mother, inquest finds
items.standfirst: Paloma Shemirani, 23, died after refusing chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma despite doctors’ concernsA woman who died after refusing chemotherapy doctors believed would have given her a strong chance of recovery was “adversely influenced” by her conspiracy theorist mother, a coroner has said.Paloma Shemirani died aged 23 in July 2024 after refusing conventional treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphoma. On Thursday, the coroner in her inquest said the influence of her parents, Kay and Faramarz Shemirani, “more than minimally” contributed to her death. Continue reading...
items.content: Paloma Shemirani, 23, died after refusing chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma despite doctors’ concernsA woman who died after refusing chemotherapy doctors believed would have given her a strong chance of recovery was “adversely influenced” by her conspiracy theorist mother, a coroner has said.Paloma Shemirani died aged 23 in July 2024 after refusing conventional treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphoma. On Thursday, the coroner in her inquest said the influence of her parents, Kay and Faramarz Shemirani, “more than minimally” contributed to her death. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Paloma Shemirani died after refusing chemotherapy treatment.
She was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
A coroner found her mother's views influenced her decision.
The mother held anti-chemotherapy beliefs.
The inquest determined the mother's influence contributed to the death.

clusters.title: Frailty in ageing populations worsened by air pollution, global review finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Frailty in ageing populations worsened by air pollution, global review finds: Coauthor of research says condition linked to heightened vulnerability and loss of independence – but is reversibleAir pollution increases the likelihood of people becoming frail in middle and old age, according to an international review of studies

items.title: Frailty in ageing populations worsened by air pollution, global review finds
items.standfirst: Coauthor of research says condition linked to heightened vulnerability and loss of independence – but is reversibleAir pollution increases the likelihood of people becoming frail in middle and old age, according to an international review of studies.People are living longer and, while this is often painted as a challenge to healthcare systems, it is also something to celebrate. There are many opportunities to increase the quality of life in old age, maximise independence and minimise the amount time spent being ill. Continue reading...
items.content: Coauthor of research says condition linked to heightened vulnerability and loss of independence – but is reversibleAir pollution increases the likelihood of people becoming frail in middle and old age, according to an international review of studies.People are living longer and, while this is often painted as a challenge to healthcare systems, it is also something to celebrate. There are many opportunities to increase the quality of life in old age, maximise independence and minimise the amount time spent being ill. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Air pollution increases frailty in middle and old age.
A global review of studies supports this finding.
Frailty is linked to vulnerability and loss of independence.
The research suggests frailty is a reversible condition.
The study highlights the impact of air quality on aging.

clusters.title: Experience: I put on the world’s first deaf rave for deaf ravers like me
clusters.neutral_headline: Experience: I put on the world’s first deaf rave for deaf ravers like me: Finding a venue was a headache. Some bookers thought it was a jokeI’ve spent my life determined to be one of a kind – perhaps because I’m a twin. During our birth, my younger-by-two-minutes brother’s umbilical cord wrapped around my neck. It cut off my air supply, which left me deaf, while his hearing was unimpaired. That’s sibling rivalry for you.I use hearing aids and am a strong lip reader, as well as being fluent in British Sign Language. When I take my aids out to sleep, you could fire a gun next to my ear and I wouldn’t stir. But with them in I have fairly clear access to sound

items.title: Experience: I put on the world’s first deaf rave for deaf ravers like me
items.standfirst: Finding a venue was a headache. Some bookers thought it was a jokeI’ve spent my life determined to be one of a kind – perhaps because I’m a twin. During our birth, my younger-by-two-minutes brother’s umbilical cord wrapped around my neck. It cut off my air supply, which left me deaf, while his hearing was unimpaired. That’s sibling rivalry for you.I use hearing aids and am a strong lip reader, as well as being fluent in British Sign Language. When I take my aids out to sleep, you could fire a gun next to my ear and I wouldn’t stir. But with them in I have fairly clear access to sound. Continue reading...
items.content: Finding a venue was a headache. Some bookers thought it was a jokeI’ve spent my life determined to be one of a kind – perhaps because I’m a twin. During our birth, my younger-by-two-minutes brother’s umbilical cord wrapped around my neck. It cut off my air supply, which left me deaf, while his hearing was unimpaired. That’s sibling rivalry for you.I use hearing aids and am a strong lip reader, as well as being fluent in British Sign Language. When I take my aids out to sleep, you could fire a gun next to my ear and I wouldn’t stir. But with them in I have fairly clear access to sound. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author organized the world's first deaf rave.
The author is deaf and uses hearing aids.
Finding a venue for the rave was challenging.
Some bookers initially dismissed the idea.
The author is a twin and experienced hearing loss at birth.

clusters.title: Anti-abortion groups furious as FDA approves generic abortion pill
clusters.neutral_headline: Anti-abortion groups furious as FDA approves generic abortion pill

items.title: Anti-abortion groups furious as FDA approves generic abortion pill
items.standfirst: Abortion rights supporters hail win for evidence-backed medicine as Evita Solutions’ generic version of mifepristone given approvalIn a move that has left anti-abortion advocates reeling, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) quietly approved a request to manufacture a new abortion pill earlier this week.Thanks to the approval, a company called Evita Solutions will be able to manufacture its generic version of mifepristone, one of two drugs typically used in most US medication abortions. A generic version of mifepristone, which was first approved as a brand-name drug in 2000, is already available on the market. Continue reading...
items.content: Abortion rights supporters hail win for evidence-backed medicine as Evita Solutions’ generic version of mifepristone given approvalIn a move that has left anti-abortion advocates reeling, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) quietly approved a request to manufacture a new abortion pill earlier this week.Thanks to the approval, a company called Evita Solutions will be able to manufacture its generic version of mifepristone, one of two drugs typically used in most US medication abortions. A generic version of mifepristone, which was first approved as a brand-name drug in 2000, is already available on the market. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The FDA approved a generic version of mifepristone, an abortion pill.
Evita Solutions will manufacture the generic mifepristone.
Anti-abortion groups expressed strong opposition to the FDA's decision.
Mifepristone is one of two drugs used in medication abortions.
A generic version of mifepristone has been available since 2000.

clusters.title: ‘Planetary health diet’ could save 40,000 deaths a day, landmark report finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Planetary Health Diet Could Prevent Deaths, Report Finds

items.title: ‘Planetary health diet’ could save 40,000 deaths a day, landmark report finds
items.standfirst: Diet allows modest meat consumption and would also slash food-related climate emissions by half, says report by 70 leading experts from 35 countriesAdoption of a plant-rich “planetary health diet” could prevent 40,000 early deaths a day across the world, according to a landmark report.The diet – which allows moderate meat consumption – and related measures would also slash the food-related emissions driving global heating by half by 2050. Today, a third of greenhouse gas emissions come from the global food system and taming the climate crisis is impossible without changing how the world eats, the researchers said. Food production is also the biggest cause of the destruction of wildlife and forests and the pollution of water. Continue reading...
items.content: Diet allows modest meat consumption and would also slash food-related climate emissions by half, says report by 70 leading experts from 35 countriesAdoption of a plant-rich “planetary health diet” could prevent 40,000 early deaths a day across the world, according to a landmark report.The diet – which allows moderate meat consumption – and related measures would also slash the food-related emissions driving global heating by half by 2050. Today, a third of greenhouse gas emissions come from the global food system and taming the climate crisis is impossible without changing how the world eats, the researchers said. Food production is also the biggest cause of the destruction of wildlife and forests and the pollution of water. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A "planetary health diet" could prevent 40,000 deaths daily worldwide.
The diet allows modest meat consumption and reduces emissions.
The report was created by 70 experts from 35 countries.
Food production is a major cause of environmental damage.
The diet would slash food-related emissions by half by 2050.

clusters.title: Call to allow ‘safe and effective’ at-home abortions up to 12 weeks in UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Call to allow ‘safe and effective’ at-home abortions up to 12 weeks in UK

items.title: Call to allow ‘safe and effective’ at-home abortions up to 12 weeks in UK
items.standfirst: Experts point to study showing procedures at home are no risker or less successful than hospital careAt-home abortions should be allowed for up to 12 weeks of pregnancy across the UK, according to academics, after a study found they were just as safe and effective as hospital care.A medical abortion involves taking two medications, mifepristone and misoprostol, to end a pregnancy. In 2022, at-home medical abortions were made permanent in England and Wales, after temporary legislation allowed them to take place at home during the pandemic. In Northern Ireland, at-home abortion care is not permitted at any gestation. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts point to study showing procedures at home are no risker or less successful than hospital careAt-home abortions should be allowed for up to 12 weeks of pregnancy across the UK, according to academics, after a study found they were just as safe and effective as hospital care.A medical abortion involves taking two medications, mifepristone and misoprostol, to end a pregnancy. In 2022, at-home medical abortions were made permanent in England and Wales, after temporary legislation allowed them to take place at home during the pandemic. In Northern Ireland, at-home abortion care is not permitted at any gestation. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Academics advocate for at-home abortions up to 12 weeks in the UK.
A study found at-home abortions are as safe as hospital care.
Medical abortions involve mifepristone and misoprostol.
At-home abortions are permanent in England and Wales.
Northern Ireland does not permit at-home abortion care.

clusters.title: Advantages of online GP booking systems | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Online GP Booking Systems: Advantages and Disadvantages

items.title: Advantages of online GP booking systems | Letters
items.standfirst: Martin Giebner says the problem is the mismatch between demand and capacity, not how appointments are booked, while Jonathan Hauxwell thinks online systems create better-targeted appointmentsGPs in England are missing a trick (GPs in England threaten action over online appointment booking plan, 29 September). The point about non-urgent GP appointments is that they do not need triage – if a patient wants to see a primary care clinician for a routine concern, they can do so, whatever the issue.The number of routine slots available remains the same, and allowing people to book them online will reduce, not increase, workload by freeing up reception staff for other admin tasks, and making it easier to get through on the phone for urgent appointments. It’s urgent requests, not routine ones, that need triage. Continue reading...
items.content: Martin Giebner says the problem is the mismatch between demand and capacity, not how appointments are booked, while Jonathan Hauxwell thinks online systems create better-targeted appointmentsGPs in England are missing a trick (GPs in England threaten action over online appointment booking plan, 29 September). The point about non-urgent GP appointments is that they do not need triage – if a patient wants to see a primary care clinician for a routine concern, they can do so, whatever the issue.The number of routine slots available remains the same, and allowing people to book them online will reduce, not increase, workload by freeing up reception staff for other admin tasks, and making it easier to get through on the phone for urgent appointments. It’s urgent requests, not routine ones, that need triage. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the pros and cons of online GP booking systems.
One letter argues the problem is demand versus capacity.
Another letter suggests online systems create better appointments.
Online booking may reduce workload by freeing up staff.
Urgent requests, not routine ones, need triage according to the article.

clusters.title: UK government owes children apology for damaging Covid errors, inquiry hears
clusters.neutral_headline: UK Government Owes Children Apology for Pandemic Errors

items.title: UK government owes children apology for damaging Covid errors, inquiry hears
items.standfirst: Children’s commissioner during pandemic says long lockdowns caused explosion in vulnerability among youngThe government should apologise to children for the damaging mistakes and policy errors it committed during the pandemic, the former children’s commissioner for England has told the Covid-19 inquiry.Giving evidence to the inquiry’s public hearing on Thursday, Anne Longfield said a “doom loop” of fatalism among ministers meant the government failed to do more to help children. She argued that the prolonged lockdowns and school closures were responsible for the explosion in mental health, welfare and behaviour difficulties still being experienced by children and young people. Continue reading...
items.content: Children’s commissioner during pandemic says long lockdowns caused explosion in vulnerability among youngThe government should apologise to children for the damaging mistakes and policy errors it committed during the pandemic, the former children’s commissioner for England has told the Covid-19 inquiry.Giving evidence to the inquiry’s public hearing on Thursday, Anne Longfield said a “doom loop” of fatalism among ministers meant the government failed to do more to help children. She argued that the prolonged lockdowns and school closures were responsible for the explosion in mental health, welfare and behaviour difficulties still being experienced by children and young people. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The former children's commissioner wants an apology for pandemic errors.
Long lockdowns caused increased vulnerability among young people.
The commissioner testified at the Covid-19 inquiry.
The government's actions led to mental health issues.
The government failed to help children during the pandemic.

clusters.title: UK politics: Jenrick’s ideas mostly ‘my thoughts repackaged’, says Badenoch – as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: Jenrick's Ideas Mostly "Repackaged," Badenoch Says

items.title: UK politics: Jenrick’s ideas mostly ‘my thoughts repackaged’, says Badenoch – as it happened
items.standfirst: Tory leader also claims the party was close to bankruptcy when she took over last yearKemi Badenoch vows to repeal Climate Change ActVoters trust the Green party most … on green issues, is the rather unsurprising finding of a poll by YouGov looking at how voters view the party, which starts its autumn conference tomorrow. The Greens are least trusted on the economy and on defence.But there is something remarkable about this. In his write-up for YouGov, Dylan Difford says:Unsurprisingly, Britons have a particular degree of confidence in the Greens when it comes to the environment. What’s notable, though, is that a majority of Britons (54%) say they have at least a fair amount of trust in the party on the issue. Out of the 18 areas polled, which have been asked about all five major parties, this is the only issue for any of the parties for where most people express confidence in a given party. Continue reading...
items.content: Tory leader also claims the party was close to bankruptcy when she took over last yearKemi Badenoch vows to repeal Climate Change ActVoters trust the Green party most … on green issues, is the rather unsurprising finding of a poll by YouGov looking at how voters view the party, which starts its autumn conference tomorrow. The Greens are least trusted on the economy and on defence.But there is something remarkable about this. In his write-up for YouGov, Dylan Difford says:Unsurprisingly, Britons have a particular degree of confidence in the Greens when it comes to the environment. What’s notable, though, is that a majority of Britons (54%) say they have at least a fair amount of trust in the party on the issue. Out of the 18 areas polled, which have been asked about all five major parties, this is the only issue for any of the parties for where most people express confidence in a given party. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Kemi Badenoch claims Jenrick's ideas are mostly repackaged.
Badenoch vows to repeal the Climate Change Act.
A YouGov poll shows the Green Party is trusted on green issues.
The Green Party is least trusted on the economy and defense.
The poll reveals public confidence in the Green Party on environment.

clusters.title: How the White House spun ‘weak’ and ‘inconclusive’ studies to tie Tylenol to autism
clusters.neutral_headline: How the White House spun ‘weak’ and ‘inconclusive’ studies to tie Tylenol to autism

items.title: How the White House spun ‘weak’ and ‘inconclusive’ studies to tie Tylenol to autism
items.standfirst: Experts say White House presented ‘association as causation’ and based conclusions on ‘poor quality studies’The White House recently issued a press release with links to scientific studies to back up Trump’s claim that use of acetaminophen, commonly referred to as Tylenol, during pregnancy causes autism, but those studies provided only “weak” and “inconclusive” evidence, according to physicians with expertise in reviewing medical research who spoke to the Guardian.Jeffrey Singer, a surgeon and senior fellow at the Cato Institute who has written about the Tylenol/autism claims, said that the links in the White House press release showed that the claims contained a political spin. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say White House presented ‘association as causation’ and based conclusions on ‘poor quality studies’The White House recently issued a press release with links to scientific studies to back up Trump’s claim that use of acetaminophen, commonly referred to as Tylenol, during pregnancy causes autism, but those studies provided only “weak” and “inconclusive” evidence, according to physicians with expertise in reviewing medical research who spoke to the Guardian.Jeffrey Singer, a surgeon and senior fellow at the Cato Institute who has written about the Tylenol/autism claims, said that the links in the White House press release showed that the claims contained a political spin. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The White House cited studies linking Tylenol to autism.
Experts say the White House presented "association as causation."
The studies provided "weak" and "inconclusive" evidence.
The claims were based on "poor quality studies."
The article suggests a political spin in the claims.

clusters.title: ‘Everything that is wrong with the human race’: inside Hollywood’s bizarre war on the leaf blower
clusters.neutral_headline: Hollywood Celebrities Express Dislike for Leaf Blowers

items.title: ‘Everything that is wrong with the human race’: inside Hollywood’s bizarre war on the leaf blower
items.standfirst: For 18 years, Cate Blanchett has railed against the hated garden gadget – and she’s not alone. From Hugh Grant to Danny DeVito, the backpack blower has united stars in unlikely, furious contemptConsider the great Hollywood feud. Perhaps Bette Davis and Joan Crawford’s mutual loathing comes to mind? Or Marlon Brando’s 40-year-old beef with Burt Reynolds? Maybe the more recent tensions between Olivia Wilde and Florence Pugh? Well, let me tell you: these are absolutely nothing compared to Cate Blanchett and her indefatigable animus towards … the leaf blower. Seemingly every single leaf blower.Truly, this is one of the greatest celebrity animosities of this century. The earliest extant Blanchett-rant on the subject is a W Magazine interview, way back in 2007, when she ambiguously characterised leaf blowers – a lot of fence-sitting here – as “everything that is wrong with the human race”. Continue reading...

From Hugh Grant to Danny DeVito, the backpack blower has united stars in unlikely, furious contemptConsider the great Hollywood feud. Perhaps Bette Davis and Joan Crawford’s mutual loathing comes to mind? Or Marlon Brando’s 40-year-old beef with Burt Reynolds? Maybe the more recent tensions between Olivia Wilde and Florence Pugh? Well, let me tell you: these are absolutely nothing compared to Cate Blanchett and her indefatigable animus towards … the leaf blower. Seemingly every single leaf blower.Truly, this is one of the greatest celebrity animosities of this century. The earliest extant Blanchett-rant on the subject is a W Magazine interview, way back in 2007, when she ambiguously characterised leaf blowers – a lot of fence-sitting here – as “everything that is wrong with the human race”. Continue reading...
